Data Assimilation for Climate Dynamics: A Quantum Mechanical Approach

Data assimilation is a framework for state estimation and prediction in partially observed dynamical systems. It employs a predictor-corrector approach, using a forward model to evolve the probability distribution of the system state until a new observation is acquired, at which time the probability distribution is updated in an analysis step to a posterior distribution correcting for model error and/or uncertainty in the prior distribution. Since Kalman's seminal work on filtering (1960), data assimilation has become an indispensable tool in modeling and forecasting of the climate system.

The climate system poses significant challenges to data assimilation due to its large number of active degrees of freedom, evolving under nonlinear and partially known equations of motion. These issues affect both forward models and analysis procedures. To address these challenges, various operational data assimilation techniques have been developed, including variational, ensemble, and particle methods.

In this work, we present a new method for data assimilation of climate dynamics that combines aspects of quantum mechanics, operator-theoretic ergodic theory, and kernel methods for machine learning. This approach results in a fully data-driven scheme, formulated entirely through linear evolution operators on spaces of observables. We demonstrate the utility of the method in a data assimilation experiment targeting the Niño 3.4 index for the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) in the Community Climate System Model Version 4 (CCSM4).

Quantum Mechanical Data Assimilation

The quantum mechanical data assimilation (QMDA) scheme employed in this work is based on the observation that the predictor-corrector structure of data assimilation resembles the dynamics and measurement formalism of quantum mechanics. The system state evolves under unitary dynamics between measurements (analogous to the forward modeling step in data assimilation) and under projective dynamics during measurements (the so-called "wavefunction collapse", analogous to the analysis step in data assimilation). Since quantum mechanics is inherently a statistical theory, formulated entirely through linear operators, it is natural to explore whether its formalism can be adapted to the context of data assimilation of classical dynamical systems.

Quantum Mechanical Data Assimilation for Climate Dynamics

To construct a concrete data assimilation scheme from the abstract quantum mechanical axioms, we employ ideas from Koopman operator theory. This framework characterizes a given measure-preserving dynamical system through intrinsically linear operators on a Hilbert space, called Koopman operators, governing the evolution of observables (functions of the state) under the dynamics. Mathematically, such Koopman operators have closely related properties to the Heisenberg evolution operators in quantum mechanics.
